comment: Very subtle taste of honey and flowers
Bought part of trip to scotland
Scotch Whiskey Experience on Edinburgh with Mari
Smooth and mild from start to finish. A little citrus.
Clean, light and sweet.  Great for drinking when it is hot outside.  Is it worth the price?  Would probably spend my bucks on Mac 10 fine oak...
Lichte caramel in de neus, in de mond eerst kruidig, dan blijft de houttoets lang aanhouden
Strong notes of flora and licorice.
A really sweet and respectable dram, but it could be cheaper for a few extra points.
Crisp, sweet, clean. Apple and honey.
Spice feels more acidic. High fruit outside the acidic bite the tone is light and airy.
A sweeter dram, appropriate as a before after dinner drink. But a pretty bland finish that leaves a little to be desired.
Like honey melted in the smoke of a campfire.  Or at least that's what I picture.  The first whiskey that prompted "goddam" in a good way.
Very dry finish. I get citrus but not the lemon they say it talks about. Decent but not a go out and buy now.
Very smooth. Easy drinking. Polite but enjoyable. A nice start to an evening of scotch drinking.
Smooth, light, easy to drink. Not remarkable, but nothing bad, either.
My home whisky.....always a bottle of these in the house.

Neutral. Clean, toasted hazelnut  nose, light pear and applewood/oak notes and a satisfying nutty-cereal flavor. Hint of lemon. Finish is medium length with an unexpected bittersweet element, not off putting, just a point of character in a mostly neutral lowland malt. Usually priced well, worth trying. Beautiful bottle shape...
Good, like aberlour 10, lemony, sweet, tequilla hit
Dry , floral , fruity and Peary too . Wonderful for the price of under 50 dollars .. Worth the money .. Still more to go , but on any day goes best with Salmon or sushi

Nostalgic after-the-rain scent of a field of tall grass and mixed flowers in southern Indiana (a feeling locked in to memories of my childhood) — sweetness of hay, quite malty, and very floral; hints of vanilla and tropical fruit (dominated by lemon) on the palate, with a subdued but bountifully spicy maltiness; tea-like bitterness in the mouthfeel with a deep burn; definitely light in body but woody enough, the finish is lengthy and peppery; aftertaste is of dry prairie grass and has a malty depth; mundane but elegant, this reminds me of Deanston Virgin Oak but with far more assertiveness and surety. A pleasure to share this dram with my dear friend Kory in celebration of his marriage!
I think this might be the lowlands representative in a set from old. The gentleness and kind of dry sweetiness I since then connect with the oowlands.
Caramel and butterscotch with hot/spicy finish
A little boring. No interesting flavors. Tried it at Mercure hotel in Edinburgh.
Very smooth.  Would be a great introduction to scotch.  Butter,  cinnamon,  and ginger flavors.  Little to no burn.  Not for me,  but a good scotch nonetheless.
Honey, orange and oak with a hint of pear. Full bodied sweetness gives way quickly to a lite fruity finish.

Typical of Lowland scotches that haven't been tinkered with cask finishing... a light malt that hits all the cereal notes (honey, vanilla, wheat) and a pleasant lightness in body.  This would be a good scotch for those beginning their malt journey.  Those looking for complexity or bold flavors should look elsewhere.
Vanilla and grain flavor.  Very nice nose, smooth palate with short finish.  Decent for price (about $60)
Smooth, solid scotch.  Fantastic nose, give that a 4.   Honey, reminds me if dahlwinnie or arbelour.   You won't be disappointed.
15 Mar 2016 at Bristol before Melanie Martinez concert
[Whiskey Live New York 2016] - Pretty basic malt.  I woudln't hold a candle up to it.
Doet aan dalwhini denken, lichte neus, met een lange finish

Nose = light oak on the nose.  Honey Nut Cheerios. Band aids.  A little sweetness.
Palate = cereal, sweetness.  
Finish = having a hard time placing the finish.

Light and clean with citrus honey and cereal sweet nose.  The thin body delivers honey and spice then quickly devolves leaving a dry oaky bland finish.  Not overly exciting.  Rather simple and boring. [82/100][Whisky on the Hudson 9/18/14; 7/12/16/Houston]
Had a dram in Inverness. Little spice, but went down really nice. Should pick up a bottle to have on hand.

Lowland whiskies tend to be overlooked by many whisky drinkers. That's a shame! Being a rather light, soft and floral Single Malt, Glenkinchie 12 has a surprising complexity. The nose is mildly grainy and fruity with honey, nuts and caramel. It's a busy nose that needs a bit of time to open up. On the palate, the dram arrives full-bodied with ripe fruits, pepper and a malty spiciness. It turns slightly dry and there is an occasional spiritiness coming through. The finish is fresh and aromatic but rather short. An easily accessible malt with a remarkable character!

RATING: 3.5/5.0 stars ≙ 83 pts → ABOVE AVERAGE

Another sample from Flaviar.  I had this one last night right after sampling the Talisker Port Ruige, while catching up on DVR recordings of Silicon Valley after a week of a business trip.  Mistake #1:  I had this after a Talisker.  It couldn't even tell if I was having plain water or a Glenkinchie.  mistake #2:  I read the label where it came from:  sample was sent from Ljubjana, Slovenia.  I started to reminesce about how beautiful Slovenia was---cute little capital, gorgeous fairy tale castle in Lake Bled, and amazing food (close to Italian border).  And then of course, if you go, you simply have to drive over to Croatia, especially Dubrovnik!! Even more amazing food, lovely beaches, beautiful architecture, and King's Landing!! Ok--back to business--- I don't think I can write much fairly for this sample.  Was totally fleeting.  A bit of honey, not much in the nose, and can't even rember the finish.   But, I do really miss Ljubjana.  I should go again one day.
Personally I think it has been underrated...I don't know if it breaks Whisky law but I was hit with instant salted caramel, followed quickly by spiced wood and finally a gentle smoke.
Light and fairly smooth, with tree fruit sweetness and soft smoke. Quite good, but I've had just as good or better for cheaper. $90 in Ontario.
Much more flavor than I was expecting. Nose strong with green apple and a bit of other sweet fruit. Sweet taste with a clean finish. I'd have to say it's quite underrated.
Set bought at Oban Distillery. $60.  Sweet, grassy, an unpleasant level of tannin and woody flavor.

Smaržā jūt mazliet dūmakainumu. Ir sajūta ka var kust arī to Lowland līdzenumu zaļuma smaržu (tikko pļautu zāli)
Pēcgarša baigi stiprā!
I really like this.  Light with lots of pear and a little apple or maybe peach.  Great summer whiskey.

@McGonagal's Pub 12/04/2016 -- suspect bottle was old, heavily oxidized.
              N: actone, damp cereal grain
              T: gentle smoke, sulpher, overcooked cabbage
              F: hot sulpher, bitter, very short.
Spicy, herby,  a touch if sweetness, grassy, a bit of malt subtle: nothing to write home about.

Color: pale yellow...with weak legs
Nose: I get pungent Sherry and weak florals
Palate:  very light body spirit... light barley,  Sherry I wasn't expecting, not much else here
Finish: short and forgettable... A disappointing dram ...The Sherry spoiled it for me...2.9
Sweet. Not too smooth. Aftertaste is meh. Smells wonderful.
Holy sweet honey flavour, finishes Smokey and light... super buttery super Smokey

Cereal grain and spice on the nose. Pleasant, mildly sweet and malty, but not much complexity on the palate. Has a bit of an afterburn and leatheriness on the finish. Decent but not a home bar necessity.
Light and floral, with spice towards the end. Strong nose and palate, but a flat finish. Decent enough whisky, but certainly not a candidate for a daily dram.

This is rightfully a 3.5. Both the nose and the palate have crisp, green apple right at the forefront, with dry hay, a bit of floral note, and a tiny hint of spice. It's not bad by any means, though it's not necessarily the flavor profile I gravitate toward.
Easy drinking. Not much flavor compared to more mature scotch options.
Sweet and fruity with a slight harsh edge at the end.
Light, which I like. Fruity, finishes better than starts
Keeping it short and sweet: Swisher sweet cigar, mezcal, margarita mix, salt. More in depth: raw honey, honeydew, mead, citrus fruit, floral cologne, musky oak, cigar leaf. An amazing and unique dram

The lightness of this whisky is one of refinement, not youngness or amateurism. Notes of heather, fruit, nuts, and a short and slightly dry finish. Pairs well with light-hearted bossa nova, like the cover of A Town With An Ocean View from the Kiki's Delivery Service soundtrack.
Very light smell, floral spring. Tingly, lemonade, casket sherry, honey. Simple to drink with enough depth to enjoy the short but deep aftertaste

Nose is fruity and fragrant. Palate is sweet but also buscuity. Finish is quite long and a slightly harsher than expected probably due to the 43% alchol percentage. A touch of water opens this up nicely though.
Had this at Rose and Crown at Epcot-I really liked this because it had that "soapy" aftertaste that reminded me of the Balvenie 17.
Basic, nothing spectacular or to get excited over.
Cereal, pears and oak, easy drinkable but with a slightly sharp whip of the alcohol.
Pleasant, but a bit bland. I was expecting more.
A smooth whisky with sweet pear and honey. The finish is not as long as I hoped, but it has quite a good depth. But all in all there are better whisky for the money.
Floral and herbaceous on the nose, with some cereal and oak spice on the palate. Otherwise a gentle spirit if it weren't for that nagging alcohol burn on the finish.
Very fruity and sweet, enjoyable bite
A bit tart with a sharp/sour finish
Gentle, sweet and smooth but doesn't have the unique flavor.
Gentle without clear flavor. Lingering aftertaste of straight alcohol.

A little harsh. Not super interesting, overall ok. Would be good mixed with a bit of cola. 

Would we buy again: probably not
Had it part of Dalwhinnie tasting to-go bag. Not bad. Not peaty.
An easy treat to have any evening. Sweet aroma and a extremely smooth taste will see you a comfortable time with this on a evening with friends. One of the lowlands highlights here. Excellent.
The most delicious and easily accessible whiskey of it's price range. Light, mellow flavour with a nose not too dissimilar to digestive biscuits.
Neutralni ale velmi stiplava chut. Ovocne tony se pripoji pozdeji do party.

I decided to put a little work in tonight on the scotch tour by banging out 3 samples in somewhat rapid succession:  anCnoc Flaughter, Aultmore 18 and this Glenkinchie 12 year old.  Paul seems to be running away with this round of samples and I gotta catch up.

The Glenkinchie is a lowland distillery located just outside of Scotland’s capital city of Edinburgh.  This 12 year old single malt has recently just replaced the 10 year in their core offering group.  It’s golden yellow in color and comes in at 43% ABV.  I believe there’s no coloring added and it’s also NCF’d.

The nose is kinda bourbon-esque:  barley, honey, vanilla and fresh cut oak are the dominant odors, with just a hint of roasted almonds coming through as well.  The flavor on the tongue doesn’t veer too far from the nose, while maybe adding some stone fruit notes, with even more oak.  The finish is welcoming, though, with some cereal notes and warm chocolate rounding it out.

This Glenkinchie and the above mentioned Aultmore are quite similar and play well together, with the unexpected harshness of the Aultmore keeping its  score down even though it has 6 more years in the cask.  Neither whisky are gold star examples for their regions, but this 12 year old gets a bump simply because of price point (which I believe is around $45-50).  A big thanks and a hearty welcome to Telex for supplying this malt.  Welcome to the team.  3.5 stars.  Cheers.
Pretty standard lowland whisky. Easy mouth feel, but heartburn finish.

Devoid of flavour and a lingering taste of alcohol was the summary of an earlier review i saw. I don't have much to add to that paraphrased statement other than it wasn't worth the cost to the environment to either make it or for me to ship the sample over from the uk.

This whisky is  bottled at 43% ABV and is a light gold in the glass. It produces average legs when given a spin. 

The nose on this dram is pleasant, light, and bright with strong floral notes and some lemon zest. Water brings out some darker tones, some dark fruit notes and a hint of smoke.

The palate is fairly sweet with honey, grass, and more floral notes. Not my favorite flavor profile but not bad...

The finish is short, slightly smoky and dry. Online price for this whisky is $58, at least for a retailer that will deliver to my area. Not a bad dram, but not one I will be looking to buy. 3.75/5 overall. Cheers!

Nose: Gentle, sweet, and spicy
Taste: "Refreshing w a creamy mouthfeel developing citrus notes in the finish " (Scotch Whisky Exp/ Aug 2017)
Very smooth and drinkable but lacked depth
Bit of an afterburn. Smooth with a honey texture. Not bad. Definitely need a drop of water.
This deserves four stars even if it is a bit bland. It still is a good drink. And great value too (40€).

​
sweet, light, buttery, flowery, quite delicious though not distinctive

Denver airport layover, and to my surprise Glenkinchie, another malt checked off my list. On the nose... floral, subtle sweetness and wood notes, the palate soft fruit, light peat, finish is fairly quick but pleasant. Would I buy a bottle, probably not but I found it a worthwhile experience.
Fairly new to Scotch and liked this quite a bit. Probably a good starter for someone who isn’t sure they’ll like whiskey.  Light, mild, lingers on the tongue with a cinnamon spice tingle. Very nice.
At lunch. Earthy, floral, soft doesn’t come on strong. A bit fruity
trop eau de vie, pas assez de goût

Nose- Citrus, plum and a bit of smoke. 
Body- Sweet honey gives way to a lighter vanilla and then green apple.
Finish- Sweetness gives way more to a very light smoke 

This is very good. Especially for the price.
Light and airy. Good for beginners or a warm afternoon.
Very good but very mainstreamy. Would drink this every day, but there is no umpf, no aah.

Nose:vanilla, honey, sweet
Palate: floral
Finish: smooth
light nose, metallic, caramel, red apple, strawberry, some tardiness 7.2
Very sweet, complex high notes with no middle or base. Floral
A nice light and sweet dram
nez de miel et vanille. miel et chêne en bouche. pas trop Sharp mais une pointe alcoolisé en bouche. overall ok scotch. j'en refuserait pas mais je n'achèterai pas la bouteille.
Light on the nose. Honey. But monotone
Light smoke. But monotone. Finish of raspberry.
Quote floral and sweet, no peat at all. A decent whisky, but not very exciting.
I usually love glenkinchie, but this one tasted a bit "green".
a solid scotch with a little bite, still it just makes me long for the flavor of my Laphroaig
Not a lot of depth but fairly smooth. A hair of spiciness. Some toffee in the nose.
my favorite scotch, it has subtle smokiness that lingers and as the scotch opens up the perfect balance of sweet fruit shines
Honey, malt and toffee on the nose. Malt, spice and oak on the tongue. The finish is long and complex, with spice, fruit and a buttery quality

Honey
Crisp apple
Hint of smoke
Very good honey tones. Very enjoyable
It is complex, not as sweet as a speyside, not as smoky as a Islay, but still a complex scotch.
Nice, soft and easy to drink
Very spicy.. smells good. Sour taste..?
pleasant, fairly unassuming.  I'd be very interested in this at cask strength

Initial. Sweet. Floral. Can taste the alcohol

Middle. Slightly stringing alcohol

Finish. add a dash of water Nd it's ok. 

nothing to impressive though
Very smooth.  Was the first single malt I drank in Scotland at the distillery.  Wonderful!
nose: sweat, taste: oak, flat KAG: soap
Pleasantly Sweet with some fruit lingering finish
Good sample of a lowland but was uninspiring
Smells honey and malt. Taste honey, vanilla and oak with malt and cream on the aftertaste.
I loved the finish. Smoky but not overpowering. Tried with Erin 2/19/19
Sharper flavors, though not over powering, smooth, but pricks the tip and sides of the tongue.
I get beer on the nose. Floral with peat and earthy notes

Recommended by barkeeper at  Doctor’s Pub near Edinburgh U.  I did ask for a local scotch but disappointed after a week of tasting in Speyside.  Light, citrus and a little grass but not complex.  Recommend moving up the price scale.

I'm confused why this isn't rated higher. It's so damn good. This is the closest to being by the sea that I've ever tasted, sans the peated whiskys.  It's briny as hell and amazing. Lemon zest and honey mixes in perfectly. Ardbeg 10 is my daily peated, and this is now my new unpeated.
Lowland whisky with the light and grassy nose and palate. A drop of water takes away the slight astringency and opens up the lemon and honey finish.
This is the quintessential boring Scotch. Fruit and grain flavors of medium strength surround a mid taste sharp, shallow burn. So middle of the road you’d swear you didn’t cross it to the officer.
middle of the road, it's ok
Exceptional for a 12 year, Very very spicy for a 43abv, but it’s nice.
Got more caramel after warming in the hands.  Best in small tastes. A big sip will kick your butt.

Nose: initially honey, followed by floral and citrus. 

Palate: mainly lemon with some oak notes, but it's not all that pronounce. 

Light body.
Really strong burn, might be because the bottle was almost empty. could have been there a while.
Full bodied and sweet nose, with a hint of spice.  Full flavor with not too much spice going down - but not as much sweetness and not as smooth.

marshmallow and meringue, a sweet whisky with a slight custard flavour adding some depth. the spirit is late and punchy, undermining the delicate flavours slightly. easy drinking and probably great in a cocktail but not enough complexity to really savour. adding water helped but detracted from the sweet notes.

Nose: Floral and pleasant, with some syrupy notes

Taste: Mellow and sweet, with a simple but easy finish. Not too complex but still decently smooth.
Light smooth flower sweety a little spicy lowland single malt whisky. No burden to try anytime.I like it :-)
Spicy flowery. Not sticky. And i prefer no adding water
Smooth, lots of flavor, a little sweet and fruity aftertaste
Very well balanced and smooth. Lacks peatiness for me though.

Bourbon is my drink of choice, and while this is not my first experience with Scotch, this is my first time attempting to review a Scotch. I received a Scotch taster box with 3 samples, and the Lowland single malt Glenkinchie 12 Year is what I am starting with. I don't know what the typical notes are in a Scotch, or if there are even "typical" notes, so I'll do my best to give an honest and accurate review. If you're a Scotch virgin like me, this review may be just what you're looking for.

The nose is bright and light with honey sweetness, slight fruit, cereal, and some underlying smokiness. There is something about the nose that reminds me of white wine, but I'm not a wine guy so who knows what that means? The mouthfeel is smooth and oily with a palate that is sweet, light, and fruity. There are not a lot of standout flavors so describing this whisky in anything but general terms is difficult. The finish is moderate with an earthy smoke and apple followed by a bit of mint. I suspect that this is a good introductory Scotch and is easy to drink. There was nothing in here that scares me away from Scotch, but also nothing to bring me back. Scotch cocktails are not something I am familiar with, but I would imagine this would be a good one to use in a cocktail. It's fine.

It’s been a while since I tried a Lowland single malt (not that there are that many to choose from, and I don’t have the $$$ to shell out for Rosebank). This is one of the single malts from the Diageo tasting kit my wife bought me, and goes with my previous reviews of Caol Ila, Cardhu, and Clynelish. 

After some time resting in the glass, the nose reveals honey, fresh cut grass, toasty malt notes, and I get a hint of pineapple. Lovely!

Palate is all creamy malt and golden honey. It reminds me of a more rounded, slightly sweeter version of the Deanston 12 or and Irish blend. The finish is relatively short bit there just the slightest nip at the end to remind you of the lovely experience you just had. 

This malt was lovely (did I mention it was lovely...). I may go so far as to even track down a bottle. Sometimes you just need something that’s easy to sip on that rewards you for minimal effort. This is that malt. Cheers!
Very smooth and light. The "Breakfast Whisky"

Nose: strong citrus notes with a hint of vanilla sweetness.

Palate: the citrus shows itself, with a Heather warmth and sweet apples following it.

Finish: very brief with the sweet apples and a bit of caramel.

Lots of honey on the nose and palate. Some floral notes and a softness that I could not place but was not honey. The taste matched the nose for me and was quite enjoyable to hold and savor. Lite and sweet. A little tingle to the finish that is enjoyable.

Last of the bottle during the craziness at Mad Fox Falls Church closing day (free 1oz pour).  Neat in a rocks glass. Well, it's a Glen. Floral, mild smoke, mild peat.  Nothing really stands out here.  Not bad, and definitely worth more than I paid for it (again, it was free). 7/21/19
Nice and light with a slightly sweet and malty backbone. A very nice sipper and great starting place as an introduction to single malt scotch.
A little oily. Some sweetness with a nice aroma. A nice scotch but not my favorite.
Exactly as the description, clean, light, fruity. Well done and should be an entry whisky for those new to the sport.
Light, floral. Lightest dram i have ever tasted.
The nose is delicate and pleasant, floral. Poor taste :( I didn't feel the flavors everyone is writing about. I will have to try again.

On the nose pear vanilla and smoke a bit.

On the palate it's rich full of aroma fruity smoky and a bit Peaty.

Good dram for a good night in a bar waiting for something
Cereal notes, toffee, light wood spice. Short finish.

First single malt tasting note:
Fruit and wood (sweet) on the nose
Oily and a bit spicy on the pallet. 
Peat and honey on the finish

Overall, smooth and easy drinking, but not my favorite.
Not a big fan of this lowland.  Better with a bit of water. Of the six distinctive single malts this is my least favorite.  Not worth a revisit, barely worth the taste try.
Nice and light. Floral and citrus notes. Easy to relax with
Apple juice that then transitions into a light weight whiskey that is a bit underwhelming, good intro whiskey if you like em sweet.

Taste:  Fruity, some light fruit taste, maybe grapes or plums but a subtle fruit flavor.  Not a bold flavor of fruit.  Easy to drink.  Medium bodied.  Not a lot to it but an easy, medium bodied scotch which tries to have character. Initial taste is good but falls off.

Nose: Sulphur, rubbery

Color: very light for scotch, yellow gold.

Finish: Inviting to drink again but not a long finish.  Lacks in the finish, but generally pleasant.

Score: 5 on a 1-10.  Enjoyable, not a select scotch but wouldn't complain if it was on happy hour.
Very good compared to other lowlands I’ve had.
Smooth no smoke/peat but good smooth scotch
Easy drinking prior to a meal

First venture to the lowlands. 

Nose: subtle floral, grains 

Palate: citrus fruits, floral. Sweet.
Smooth easy drinking scotch. Very mellow with no after taste. Would highly recommend as an entry scotch!
A delicate palate with soft toasted malt notes. Not too heavy on the palate and has an inviting warming sensation. Very tasty for a 12 years expression.
Sweet in the front and peaty at the end. Tastes of Scotland.
Smooth. Mellow. Easy drinking. Sweet smell. Oily feel. Sweet flavor. Peaty after taste.
Fin doft men smakar inte mycket. Vattnig.
It’s ok. Smells like apple juice.
Light and fruity and grassy and herbaceous
Vanilla, fruit, oak, slightly bitter, slightly smokey
The spice and vapors are too much. Harsh mouthfeel, could not even cut with water or soda.

On the nose, I am getting a mix of apples, oranges, heather, and grandma’s sweet tea.  For the palate, I get a bright splash of subtle banana, pineapple, vanilla, and light fruit. A very light mouth coat, and two finishes. One is a short, almost bitter finish, and the other wave is buttery oil, which was fairly long. This makes me think of “Double Vision” by Foreigner. I will say that even though this is far from my wheelhouse, it’s a pleasant dram. 3.25.

Stop number 46 on the SDT is Glenkinchie. Only my second of the Lowland distilleries, this 12 year old is one of Diageo's Classic Malts of Scotland. Bottled at 43% ABV, chill filtered and has colorant added making it a yellow gold. 

The nose has a ton of honey and orchard fruits. Oranges, lemons, pears and baked apples. A little toffee and butterscotch and a nice warm vanilla. Very light oak and a bit of a floral note. Buttery biscuits and a touch salty. Really quite enjoyable in its light and fruity nature. Not super complex, but good. 

A very light arrival on the palate, but the development has a burst of flavors. Some underripe fruits like apples, pears and grapes. Lots of honey and vanilla. Slightly sour, but good. A bit nutty, like pecans or perhaps walnuts. It's also a little savory with buttered biscuits and tea. 

A fairly light bodied mouthfeel, creamy and rich. 
A medium long finish that is slightly bitter oak and honey. Dry. 

I have to say I was not expecting anything here after trying Auchentoshan earlier in the tour. This Lowland has Speyside levels of flavor and a profile that isn't so different from its northerly neighbors. The nose is a little on the tame side, but the palate makes up for it before it's somewhat bitter finish. At around $50 it's a decent price but not great. A good summertime dram. I could also see having this with a mild meal. A touch of sherry maturation would have really made this a great dram. As is I give it a 3.75. Thanks to Telex for the sample. 
Cheers
vanilla scents give way to citrus and toffee flavor

シンプルで雑味もなく飲みやすい。
Simply it doesn’t have miscellaneous tastes.

物足りないとおもうこともあるかもしれない。
Someone thinks unsatisfied this taste.

Nose: Initial honeyed tones followed closely by earthy, farmyard aromas and wildflowers (calliopsis). A slightly sour fermented-hay note and cooking oil in the background. There is a nutty ale-like aroma as well. There's a lot going on here but it takes a while to open.

Palate: The arrival is faintly spicy together with herbal honey - rather like spiced mead - and it has a tannic, woody character that expands in the development. Sour/bitter malt with a metallic astringincy reminiscent of quince or unripe persimmon. The texture is both lightly oily and slightly gripping.

Finish: Medium. The flinty fruitiness of the palate fades into an unusual herbal flavour that is what I would imagine chewing dandelions would taste like.

An unusual malt that I disliked at first, then eventually came to appreciate, but never really enjoyed. It is a confused and confusing dram.

The nose is basically floral in character but not in any manner that is typically encountered. It's not honeyed nor freshly floral, not light nor heavy. It's more acrid herbal, like the aroma of crushed daisies and there is an agricultural quality. I hesitate to use the word "funk" as it has become so deplorably overused in the last year or so that it has become a cliché, but yes - there is a sense of that here. The palate was inferior to the nose, being sharper and lacking heft. It's not what I'd call a balanced malt.

Adding water did nothing for the nose - it muted what character was there into insignificance. I thought it did improve the palate, however, by plastering over the less agreeable notes.

This was a hard one to rate. It does have individuality and character but while it is not actually flawed I didn't think it was very pleasant. I tasted it from a 30ml commercial sample and I'm thankful I don't have to regret having bought a whole bottle.

When I was last in Edinburgh I had an opportunity to visit the distillery but did not do so. I went to the Scottish National Gallery with Mrs Cascode instead. It was the right choice.

"Adequate" : 1.75 stars

Nose - grains and honey, red apple, a bit of lemon zest
Taste - jalapeño right off the bat, it’s a combination of vegetal and spice, some honey and fresh fruit notes in the background
Finish - the jalapeño spice lingers for awhile, mixed with a light sweetness, just a light heat going down

My first Lowland Whisky. I had a mini bottle of it, the worst looking mini bottle i have, i had no expectation for it and it suprised me. 

Bottled at 43% abv, pale gold color. 

On the nose is rather good, there is an alcohol note that can't be avoided but doesn't change the fact that it smells good. Perfumed notes of Vanilla and prunes can be found in a pleasant way.

On the palate is also nice, with a pleasant tobacco, oak and black pepper. A little hot, but nice. medium bodied, has also a medium finish with spices.

Listen to me, add two drops of water to this baby. It is rare when water makes a whisky better, this is one of those cases.

After Water i got: On the nose, Toffee and spices that makes your nose tickle. On the Palate: More hotness BUT THICK. it changed into a full bodied experience with bitter chocolate but thick and very mellowed. Finish became  better, with tobacco notes. 

Recommended Dram!
Almost like black label but a little more spicy and less smoky than one. Fruity like a white wine
Sweet with a hint of iodine. Too much seaweed for my palate.
Flaviar Sample: first Lowland. Nose is astringent/chemical at first, then floral with grass and slight tobacco and pear. Palate is mildly sweet, minimal smoke. Started rough but grew on me

It seems smooth and simple at first, but gets more interesting and layered if you give it time. Honey and vanilla with notes of green apple on the nose. Sweet and sour continues on the palate, like golden kiwi. Then some spice and oaky notes appear. Fresh apricot and some nutty flavors as well. Not simply a “light” Lowland as some reviews claim, there is certainly variety of aromas and flavors. Give it time and you will appreciate its delicate complexity.
delicate floral nose; surprisingly insistent peat flavor, but not overpowering
